channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pardon Plea by Adolf Eichmann, Nazi War Criminal, Is Made Public
item.description: Israel released the handwritten letter by Mr. Eichmann in which he denies guilt, saying Nazi officials like him were “mere instruments in the hands of leaders.”
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Adolf Eichmann’s handwritten letter in German from 1962 requesting a pardon was made public on Wednesday in Jerusalem by the Israeli president’s office.

item.title: Human Rights Watch Denounces Europe Over Migrant Crisis
item.description: European governments have allowed fears about migration and terrorism to erode their commitment to civil rights, the group said in a new report.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Macedonian soldiers blocked the border with Greece in November.

item.title: Italians Mock Cover-Up of Nude Statues for Iranian’s Visit
item.description: To avoid offending President Hassan Rouhani on his visit to Rome, one critic wrote, “we offended ourselves.”
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, left, and Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, next to a statue of the emperor Marcus Aurelius at the Capitoline Museums in Rome on Monday.

item.title: German Cabinet Backs Measures to Ease Deportation of Criminals
item.description: The legislation would allow the authorities to send back anyone convicted of homicide, bodily harm, sexual assault, violent theft or serial shoplifting.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Whittlesey Journal: Archaeologists in England Tackle Mystery of Prehistoric Village’s Rapid Demise
item.description: The Must Farm site in Cambridgeshire, destroyed by fire 3,000 years ago, is considered so rich that it has been compared to Pompeii.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Knight, the director of the Must Farm archaeological site, said that “an event, like a big fire, basically caught their everyday life, dropped it into our channel and sealed it there for us to excavate.”

item.title: French Justice Minister Quits Over Plan to Strip Citizenship From Terrorists
item.description: The resignation of Christiane Taubira, widely known as an independent spirit with a bent more leftist than that of the Socialist government, came abruptly.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Justice Minister Christiane Taubira of France in Paris this month. She resigned on Wednesday.

item.title: Ai Weiwei Says He’s Closing Danish Exhibition in Protest of Refugee Law
item.description: The Faurschou Foundation, a contemporary art gallery in Copenhagen, confirmed on Facebook and Instagram that Mr. Ai’s “Ruptures” would end ahead of schedule.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA
item.media:description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei helped migrants arriving on the Greek island of Lesbos on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Says It Will Step Up Defenses if China Fails to Act Against North Korea
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Beijing must do more to curb the North, or the U.S. will take measures China opposes, including deploying defense systems to protect allies in Asia.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and the Chinese foreign minister, Wang Yi, in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Taliban Sabotage Cuts Major Power Source for Afghanistan Capital
item.description: The destruction of an electrical tower exposed a vulnerability in the nation’s infrastructure at a time when rebels have government forces thinly stretched.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Electricity cables in Kabul. Afghanistan suffers from a chronic power shortage, with less than 40 percent of the population even connected to the grid, according to World Bank data.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Right-Wing Attack on India’s Universities
item.description: The R.S.S., a Hindu nationalist organization, is making a play for control of Indian intellectual life.
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How China Lost Taiwan
item.description: Decades of de facto independence have whetted Taiwanese appetites for the real thing.
item.dc:creator: NICK FRISCH
item.media:description: Former law professor and trade negotiator Tsai Ing-wen was elected president on Jan. 16.

item.title: China Urging Afghanistan to Restart Peace Talks With Taliban
item.description: A statement from the Chinese Foreign Ministry suggested that Beijing was asserting a commitment to the peace process.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Wang Yi, left, the Chinese foreign minister, walking with his Afghan counterpart, Salahuddin Rabbani, on Tuesday at the Foreign Ministry in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere: Studies Point to Inequalities That Could Strain Chinese Society
item.description: Two new reports suggest that while Chinese people remain wedded, though not always blissfully, to the status quo, President Xi Jinping confronts a persistent undercurrent of discontent.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese office workers in Beijing. While incomes have risen, research points to rising inequality in wealth and access to education, health care and other social benefits.

item.title: Vietnam’s Communist Party Gives Old-Guard Leader a New 5-Year Term
item.description: The reappointment of Nguyen Phu Trong is unlikely to alter the country’s strategic balance in relations with China and the United States.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong of Vietnam, left, with Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung at the Communist Party’s national congress in Hanoi, a day before Mr. Trong’s reappointment.

item.title: Iranian Released in Prisoner Exchange Finds Fault With Its Handling
item.description: Nader Modanlo, released by the United States this month in a prisoner exchange with Iran, was reluctant to accept the deal because it required him to abandon an appeal of his conviction.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nader Modanlo at his apartment in Bethesda, Md. He was one of seven people freed by the United States in the Jan. 16 prisoner exchange with Iran.

item.title: Sinosphere: Scalping Tickets to the Doctor? Woman in Beijing Has Had Enough
item.description: A video of a woman denouncing those who resell hospital access for a profit was widely circulated online this week, inciting outrage among many.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Friends and Refugees in Need
item.description: A tidal wave of people threatens to overwhelm our top ally, the E.U.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Henry Worsley, a British Adventurer Trying to Cross Antarctica, Dies at 55
item.description: Mr. Worsley abandoned his 1,000-mile trek only 30 miles from his goal after suffering from exhaustion and dehydration.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Henry Worsley in 2008 during a training run in Greenland. His fascination with Antarctica was lifelong.

item.title: Malaysia Closes Investigation Into Prime Minister Najib Razak’s Funds
item.description: The attorney general’s decision appears to prolong the premiership of Mr. Najib, who has struggled to explain the nearly $700 million sent to his personal accounts.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia outside Parliament in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday. His government has moved aggressively to shut down leaks that led to an investigation into his personal accounts.

item.title: How Iran Rejoined the World’s Economy in Just 10 Days
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani is visiting Europe, meeting the pope, inking business deals and signaling that Iran is again engaging with the world.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran with Pope Francis at the Vatican on Tuesday.
